description:
On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared: people will be banned from leaving their place of residence as of Mar 23. 
Exempt from the measure are: those are important for transport that is necessary for supply, daily migrations, the employed in important services for healthcare and veterinary protection, delivery of medicines, sanitary materials, maintaining utilities, water supply and sewage, provision of natural gas and electricity, informing the public, journalists, citizens that require urgent medical assistance, vital family reasons, travelling to work and from work if doing a job is absolutely necessary and can’t be done from home, as well as urgent operative services that are taking part in preventing spread of the disease.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Feb 24 2020 the Croatian Ministry of Health raised the alert level due to the risk of coronavirus.
type_sub_cat: NA

description:
On Mar 5 2020 the Croatian Minister of Health has adopted the decision to declare the risk of an epidemic of the infectious disease Covid 19. It is an administrative measure that does not indicate the degree of threat but allows the Minister to mobilize all resources in the healthcare system, to relocate infectious diseases doctors and other healthcare professionals and equipment as needed, thus enabling better management of the healthcare system. 
The decision of declaration of epidemic diseases Covide-19 in the whole Republic of Croatia was implemented on Mar 11 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On Feb 24 the Crisis Headquarters of the Croatian Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including increased surveillance of border crossings to Italy.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Croatia is banning transit through all its border crossings for 30 days, excluding cross-border workers, freight carriers, healthcare professionals, diplomats and transit passengers on March 19.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On Mar 30 the Republic of Croatia temporarily closes six permanent border crossings (Umag, Porec, Rovinj, Mali Lošinj, Korcula and Ubli) and postpones the opening of eleven seasonal crossings (Umag-ACI Marina, Novigrad, Sali, Božava, Primošten, Komiža, Hvar, Vis, Stari Grad on the island of Hvar, Vela Luka and Cavtat) for international passenger traffic in maritime transport.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On Mar 31 The Croatian Ministry of the Interior said the border regime would be relaxed allowing Croatian and Hungarian citizens living or working within 30 km of the border to cross the border every day or when necessary. The relaxed sanitary measures refer only to those who have a justified reason to cross the border in order to perform work that is considered economically important as well as to persons who own farms in the other country.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Apr 2 Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina have agreed to temporarily close 20 of their mutual border crossings. The traffic is thus suspended at the following border crossings: Svilaj, Gejkovac, Pasin Potok, Bogovolja, Kordunski Ljeskovac, Licka Kaldrma, Bili Brig, Arzano Pazar, Dvorine, Cera, Jovica Most, Sebisina, Slivno, Podprolog, Unka, Vukov Klanac, Imotica, Slano, Hrvatska Dubica and Gabela Polje.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On Feb 27 the Government of the Republic of Croatia approved the amount of HRK 2,250,000 to finance the procurement of nine artificial ventilation devices, to provide the necessary prerequisites for preventing further spread and treatment of coronavirus.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 19 Croatian troops began erecting a tent for a medical camp outside the Dubrava hospital in Zagreb with a capacity of 270 beds to accommodate infected patients and it is expected to be erected by Saturday.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On Mar 20 Hospital beds are being installed in Zagreb's Arena concert hall for patients who are not in a serous condition and who are being cared for in local hospitals, and their transfer will be organised, if necessary, to free up hospital capacities for coronavirus patients.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 29 the Croatian government has secured more than 20 tons of protective masks, protective suits and protective goggles from China.
type_sub_cat: Masks
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Mar 31 the Croatian Science Foundation with financing from the Ministry of Science and Education has invited scientists to apply for 14 million kuna in grants for research related to the coronavirus. The research is not limited to medicine and public health, but also the social aspects of the pandemic and its effects on the education system. The researchers have 18 months to complete their projects.
type_sub_cat: Masks
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 3 the Croatian Andrija Stampar Teaching Institute of Public Health has introduced drive-in testing for coronavirus, the first in Croatia to do so, which will speed up the diagnosis process and increase the number of tests.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On April 9, the Croatian city, Dubrovnik, started a drive-in testing for coronavirus in front of the Student dormitory in Cokolino, a facility that has become secondary accommodation for coronavirus patients.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: On Mar 4 2020 the Croatian Institute for Public Health issued new recommendations regarding the disinfection of ambulance vehicles and sanitary vehicles: buses, trains, ships and aircraft as well as recommendations for carrying out transport activities.
type_sub_cat: Hygiene measures for public areas
type_text: disinfection of ambulance vehicles and sanitary vehicles

description: On May 4th, both hair and beauty salons will be opening up with hygiene regulations including: mandatory posting of information on hygiene, social distancing (1.5 meters) between clients and staff (Plexiglass barrier recommended for regular cleaning and disinfection), disinfectants (must be available in waiting rooms/entrance area, payment desk, and work area). It is recommended that towels and gowns are replaced by disposable towels and gowns and that both staff and clients wear gloves and face masks.
type_sub_cat: Hygiene measures for public areas

description: On Apr 1 the Croatian coronavirus crisis team declared that as of April 6 leaving one's place of residence will be possible only with an e-pass. The e-passes will be issued for a period of one to fourteen days, depending on the reason.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On Feb 13 the Croatian Government has established the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia to coordinate all services in the event of the occurrence of COVID-19 coronavirus in Croatia.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On 2 February 2020 in cooperation with Croatian and French authorities, four Croatian nationals, among 250 passengers from fifteen European countries, were evacuated from China and arrived by a special French aircraft to the Istres military airport near Marseille.

description: On Mar 30 the Croatian Police Directorate has called upon all foreigners on short stay in Croatia who are not able to leave Croatia to send their information to the police in order to be registered.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: registration of foreigners who are unable to leave Croatia

description: On January 23, at the initiative of the Ministry of Health, the Croatian Institute of Public Health has published a multilingual leaflet and a notification on coronavirus for travellers to China (in Croatian, English and Chinese).
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: 26 February 2020 The daily sessions of the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia were introduced at 9 am and 4 pm, after which press releases were issued and published on the website Civil Protection Directorate.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 18, the Croatian government established a COVID-19 call centers where epidemiologists and other professionals can answer citizens questions every day from 8am to 4pm.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On April 14, the Croatian Ministry of Health introduced Andrija - the first digital coronavirus assistant in Croatia. The app helps people recognize symptoms of coronavirus infection (self-assessment of their own health status), connects people to competent institutions, allows people to report relevant information from their household, and helps nursing home employees understand health protocols.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On April 27, the  The Croatian Institute of Public Health and the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Croatia established an Open Data Portal which collects data regarding COVID-19 and ensures transparency with real-time data that citizens can access at any time.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On 2 February 2020 after the evacuation of four Croatian nationals, who arrived by a special French aircraft from China to the Istres military airport near Marseille, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs ordered their isolation due to precautionary measures to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus epidemic. They were kept in quarantine for 14 days i.e. during the incubation time of the disease.
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Feb 21 the Croatian Institute of Public Health initiated the quarantine of persons who were identified or suspected to have been in direct contact with patients with COVID-19 while on board ships. The designated quarantine unit is at the Infectious Diseases Clinic “Dr Fran Mihaljevic” in Zagreb.
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine

description:
On Feb 24th, Croatian Crisis Headquarters of the Ministry of Health presented additional measures that Croatia will take against the spread of coronavirus including: 
All travellers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy. For all persons who have been in close contact with a patient, self-isolation is foreseen in their own home with daily contact with the epidemiologist or organized quarantine if there are no conditions for self-isolation.
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:

All travelers coming from the affected areas are foreseen to be placed in self-isolation with health surveillance and are obliged to report daily to the epidemiologist. The affected areas include China, the Republic of Korea (South Korea) and the provinces of Lombardy and Veneto in Italy.
type_sub_cat: Other Quarantine

description: On March 12 the Croatian Interior Minister Davor Božinovic announced Croatia added more countries to a list of those whose nationals will have to be quarantined if they want to enter the country. These measures apply to citizens of Germany, France, Switzerland, Spain, Austria, the UK, the Netherlands, and Sweden. They will be required to undergo strict self-quarantine measures.

description: On Mar 26 the Croatian Ministry of Interior declared to liberalize the procedure related to Croatian and foreign citizens that drive for Croatian employers in international transport. Following loading or unloading they can be in self-isolation at their homes and no longer have to go into quarantine. If they notice any kind of symptoms they must contact their doctors.

description: Mar 14 Istria County his shuttering all hospitality businesses for the next month in a move to try and curb the spread of the coronavirus. All cafes and restaurants will be closed until April 14. Food delivery services and soup kitchens are exempt but are under strict cautionary measures, said Damir Kozlovac, the head of county civil defense services.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description:
On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description: On Mar 22 the Croatian Ministry of Interior ordered the closure of farm produce markets.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description: On Mar 27 Croatian coronavirus task force allowed stores that have indoor spaces to reopen, in an effort not to completely strangle economic activity while keeping the coronavirus from spreading rapidly through the population.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description: On April 27, all stores in Croatia, except those operating within big shopping centres, will again be permitted to open.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description:
On March 19 the Croatian government ordered the suspension of all businesses for 30 days with the exception of grocery stores, food and hygiene items, market and fish markets, specialized stores selling and dispensing (pharmacies), specialized stores selling and dispensing veterinary medicinal products, agricultural pharmacies, gas stations, kiosks, bakery, chemical laundry, specialized stores selling orthopedic and other aids, specialized baby equipment stores, specialized animal feed stores, issuance of construction materials based on retail order
logistic and distribution centers for food, beverages and hygiene products and wholesalers. The new policy is that on April 27, the Croatian government permitted all shops, except those operating within big shopping centers, to open again.
type_sub_cat: Non-Essential Commercial Businesses

description: On April 27, all stores in Croatia, except those operating within big shopping centres, will again be permitted to open. Big shopping centers are able to reopen effective May 11.

description: 9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On Mar 12 the Croatian government recommended postponement or limitation of gatherings with more than 100 people, as well as sports events without spectators.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 19, Croatian government cancelled religious services (all public events, gatherings, and meetings of more than 5 persons in one place). The policy ended on May 2, allowing religious services to resume.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: 9 March 2020 the Croatian National headquarters for coronavirus introduced new measures to prevent spreading of virus: It is recommended to postpone all public events with more than 1000 people. If organizers however decide to organize such events, they must ensure high hygienic standards. On Mar 12 the Croatian government recommended postponement or limitation of gatherings with more than 100 people, as well as sports events without spectators. Effective March 19, all sports competitions will be closed.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 21, the government of Croatia announced that only immediate family and religious community representatives may attend funerals. This measured was extended until May 4 with the following precautionary measures: no music, flowers or candles, and obituaries may not contain information on the time and place of the funeral
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On March 19 Croatia is putting a ban on the gathering of more than 5 people in one place for 30 days. The policy was updated on beginning May 11, where public gatherings of up to 10 people were allowed outdoors.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description:
On Mar 21 the Croatia national civil protection authority decided to suspend all public transportation services, including transport by rail, bus and tram, for the next 30 days, and the decision goes into force on Sunday, March 22.
All railway and bus stations will be closed. Travel to islands will be possible only for people who live on islands.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 14, the Croatian Institute of Public Health issued recommendations of social distancing for visitors at  beaches as well as freshwater and sea swimming areas. These recommendations include  a maximum number of 15 people per one hundred square meters on the beaches and maintaining 1.5 m physical distance between individuals in the water.
